_Mhrs8RlDoud1BK0l2ySNw.text: My mother and I like to brunch here. Admittedly, I'm not a huge antipasti fan, but I still manage to find amazing things that I love. And then I always go with the cannelloni or pollo panini. She always goes with a pasta - gnocchi or pollo limone. You really can't go wrong. It's bright, cheery and warm inside the building - makes for a lovely Sunday brunch.   My brothers, younger than me with basic American taste buds, hate it here - far too traditional for them. So, I suppose it's very palate based. Maybe not the best restaurant for children.

_F29-1dkiBmDPSaKQ9_O0Q.text: Beautiful atmosphere, but totally overrated.  Unfortunately, we went here to celebrate my hubby's bday, and when we left he told me that he would have rather gone to the Grand Concourse, LOL!  I guess I expected fabulous--but everything was just good, nothing spectacular.  First off, our waiter was in training, and even though we met his mentor, she didn't seem to keep tabs on him.  Small things were overlooked, like no coffee refills or spoons, tons of dirty dishes and empty glasses on the table.  He was accommodating, but we had to ask for too many things multiple times.  The one thing that REALLY IRRITATED me was that I saw one of the young waiters who was serving the pasta from the serving platters, stick his fork in one of the platters and shove the ravioli in his mouth as he was standing right in the door of the kitchen.  Truly, made me sick--was glad my hubby and daughter had already eaten their ravioli.  :-/  The food--Two of us had the pasta trio, meh--the ravioli was good, not so much for the other two dishes.  One of us had the cannelloni and ate it all up.  One of us had the pork loin dish--it was dry but tasty.  And then I had the lemon chicken.  It was actually good, right up my alley with bright notes of lemon and caper!  But, my favorite thing was the antipasta bar--the dessert bar was little to be desired.    We will not be back.

G3riBwmWsG16tPibwB7uDA.text: Service was excellent.  The menu offerings were spotty.  A group 16 of us attended the Saints-Steelers game in November.  We attend most of the away games and have an opportunity to eat at some very good restaurants.    Lidia's was a place I was looking forward to because I am aware of her by reputation.   We had several appetizers including the bruschetta, which was really only to my liking.  The balsamic was excellent - syrupy and sweet - and clearly a nicely aged one.  But it was incongruous with the rest of the dish, and so not many enjoyed it.    The bread served at the table was really very good and we devoured baskets of it.   Comments from some of the other diners:  - Baked shrimp appetizer was pretty good, the calamari was very good.   - Rucola  salad was (in my opinion) excellent - Beet salad was interesting and overall very good - Butternut squash soup was enjoyed by several of us - Scampi alla Felidia was ordered by several guests with mixed opinions - Lasagna bolognese?  so so at best  Gnocchi and duck ragu was what I ordered.  I was very disappointed. The duck was shredded and cooked into a sort of red congealed, thick mass with little texture.  The gnocchi were so underdone as to be a sort of glutinous paste sitting under the duck.  The texture was completely unappealing but I do have to say that the flavor of the duck ragu (ragout?) was pretty good.   Still, the gnocchi - one of my favorite things and something I make myself probably once a month - were a disappointment.  I didn't send it back because it didn't seem appropriate in the setting of a very large group to monopolize the wait staff.    I'd still give it a try again when I'm there in June, but it seems that some of their efforts are focused more on being creative, which is good, but falling somewhat short.  By the way, if you like a more traditional Italian and happen to be in St. Louis, Charlie Gitto's on the Hill is a great place. Similar in ambiance and quality to Lidia's, the service there can't be beat and the food is quite good as well.

__eUf_UVNFZ22fHmyVSdVg.text: Sorry to say, restaurant is riding on its former reputation. For starters, it could use a good deep cleaning. Visible dust accumulation, and really "old" odor. A real turn off. Staff for most pArt were very pleasant and pasta was excellent like always. Service at tables excellent. The bartender doesn't belong in the business. Rude to patron and to his own colleagues. He explained that the special menu at the bar was an entirely separate business fr the restaurant and we could not order fr regular menu. A turn off.

IdP0t4DDBcrY8QCYm_mDQQ.text: SO DISAPPOINTED! I love Lidia Bastianich, I enjoy watching her on PBS especially when she cooks her "traditional" Italian foods, red sauce, Bolognese, pastas, meats etc. In addition we have many of Lidia's cook books, and I personally cook Italian all the time and if I say so I am a very good cook. We have not been to Lidia's in awhile and remember it to be good. Not so much this time!   The server even though she said she has worked at Lidia's for over 10 years seemed a bit distracted, she was adequate, but not completely focused, which I could get by. We started with salads, which were mostly just OK, my wife ordered the Caesar which came highly recommended, it was flavorless (which seemed to be the theme of the evening) and 80% of the Romaine lettuce was the inner rib of the leaf, which is tough and bitter. If the kitchen had any pride in the food it presents they would take the time to clean the lettuce properly, especially for a Caesar, she did not finish it and it was taken off the check.   I ordered the Zuppa Di Pesce, a classic Italian seafood dish, which if prepared correctly should have enormous flavors from the shell fish broth, and normally would be perfect for dunking a great piece of crusty Italian bread, not so much and in fact the bread that came with it was burnt! All of the seafood was so overcooked that it was not eatable! calamari, was not rubbery, but hard as a rock, the lobster tail was impossible to get out of the shell it was cooked so much. The broth literally had 0 flavor. It was to be served with Couscous, an inexpensive Israeli pasta, I swear there were 10 pieces of the pasta, crazy. I asked for more which they brought but by that time I had decided that the dish was uneatable, I mean really at an Italian restaurant. I was so disappointed that I did not order anything else! The other dishes that were served were fine, not great just average. Plus, my opinion would be to quit with the Pasta Trio, dish seems a bit DONE!!!  I also drive for Uber part time, and have taken many people who have been in Pittsburgh for business to the airport, and several of them have said that they did it at Lidia's, but thought it was just OK!  This is sad for an Italian family with the reputation of the Bastianich's to be serving food like this that leaves a customer not wanting to return or recommend it to any one!!!

pRjCU1bYQQp7WWrbST4R5Q.text: I think this place is good but over-hyped and over-priced for what it is.  I had the pasta trio and I got the combo which came with a Ceasar salad and a dessert.  The pasta trio by itself is $18 but with the salad and dessert is $32 (an extra $14, so not such a great deal!).  $18 for pasta with no meat or seafood in it is already way overpriced and ought to come with a soup or salad anyway.  So I was expecting this to be an amazing Ceasar salad but it was the worst I've ever had at a nice restaurant.  Instead of romaine lettuce, most of the lettuce was iceberg!  And the dressing was too vinegary and did not taste very good.  And I had hoped being an Italian place they would offer anchovies on it, but that was not the case.    The pasta trio was tasty and included a goat cheese ravioli with cream sauce, a fettucine with sundried tomatoes, and a penne with a pork ragu sauce.  All were good but I felt like they had been sitting out for awhile and didn't taste freshly cooked, and the texture of one of the pastas was slightly chewy.  It was fun to see them all come over with their bowls though and the guy with the parmesan was also right there ready to grate some fresh cheese for you.    For the bread, instead of butter they had these interesting things made out of a couple different sorts of bean which tasted rather like a hummus so that was interesting though would have been nice if the bread was warm.   I had the tiramisu for dessert which was good but nothing amazing.    The atmosphere was really nice with some interesting artwork and chandeliers and the service was prompt and polite.  However the food was kind of disappointing.  Honestly I think I like Olive Garden better and they have much better prices.

xrT_EGz45Z0d_ibqoEP8Bw.text: Once again Yelp has Lidia's pegged perfectly at 3.5 stars - I'm going back and forth myself between 3 and 4 stars.  Lidia's is a surprisingly large space which is decorated nicely and has great service.  The food however, is good but by no means mind blowing.  Their signature Pasta Trio lets you try 3 different pastas (served out of a pan tableside) and then choose if you want to get seconds on any of them.  All of the pastas are cooked perfectly and fresh but the sauces just don't blow me away, they are missing that last ingredient or two which would take them from good to excellent.  Given that I had better pasta at a place called Meat & Potatoes the next evening I think says something.  Bread served at the beginning of the meal is warm and really outstanding, but the spreads weren't exciting.  The wine list is nice and the atmosphere is generally upscale but friendly.  Now that I think back about Lidia's, I have to say I do appreciate the homemade pasta and I'll potentially be back but it's just a bit on the pricey side for Pittsburgh so I have to presume they're going on the name at this point.

DT5yQ-_Pf_hYq22rZZ7u4g.text: I stopped by here with my wife a couple of Tuesdays ago for dinner.  My wife and I go to the Strip District fairly often and whenever we pass Lidia's I always comment on how I haven't been there in a long time.  So whenever a three course tasting with a bottle of wine popped up on Groupon, I quickly purchased it and made the reservations for us.  The inside of Lidia's is a really nice looking place with the walls having nice shades of yellow, an exposed beams ceiling, a huge fireplace in one corner, some cutouts in the walls with bottles of wine from Italy and tables covered in white tablecloths.  Since we had purchased the groupon our meals were pretty much predetermined for us.  We started off our meal with a caesar salad that had grana padano cheese on it.  Whenever it was delivered to our table I was impressed with the size of it as it took up a whole dinner plate.  While I enjoyed the salad immensely, I can imagine that someone who doesn't like as much dressing as myself would find the salad to be overdressed.  Our entrees ended up being the pasta trio which you are able to get refilled as many times as you want.  On this night the trio consisted of a spaghetti with tomato and herb sauce, an orecchiette with sausage and broccoli rabe and a gnocchi with sage butter sauce.  My favorite of the bunch had to have been the gnocchi as the gnocchi itself was light and fluffy and the sauce was seriously amazing.  The orecchiette was my second favorite and I enjoyed the addition of the sausage and broccoli rabe to it.  My least favorite of the bunch was the spaghetti which seemed a little boring compared to the rest.  I did really enjoy the al dente pasta from it though.  Our dessert was supposed to be the tiramisu but since I am unable to each chocolate I asked the server if it was possible to substitute in another dessert.  If it wasn't possible then my wife was going to be in luck as we would have just taken mine home.  Thankfully though they were able to substitute another dessert in and I ended up choosing the ice cream trio.  I can only remember the mascarpone and blood orange granita as the flavors that I had and its worth it to note that each ice cream came with a cute miniature cookie.  The blood orange granita was easily my favorite of the bunch as it was like eating italian ice with the flavor being slightly sour and also slightly sweet.  The bottom line for me is that I will head back to Lidia's again in the future.  I was pleasantly surprised by how good Lidia's really was and I could see myself going back here again in the future just to have the pasta trio.

KdNyHND5dkqG_NZFSw5zwQ.text: Pretty bad. For an established restaurant, it seems to be run by novices. Steering customers away from their signature offering, the pasta trio, because they are "busy" isn't acceptable. I watched as two tables near us were brought the wrong dishes. The servers seemed confused. I really wanted to like this, but there's no reason to go here with all the other options available. While not perfect, exponentially better than Lidia's is Eleven, nearby on Smallman.

HlR5CtRIRSIjP83vp5892Q.text: Made a lengthy trip as a surprise birthday gift by family.    Was treated splendidly by the wait staff and even receive 2 birthday desserts as first one was missing the candle.    Had Osso Bucco with barley rissoto.     Very tasty.

_GkGqgEM-VPtFSv3tzsmhQ.text: So disappointing....I was so looking forward to a good pasta dinner!  I never got to taste any pasta.   The Caesar salad was soggy and the service was so slow we ended up leaving without even getting our dinners. We waited 40 minutes after finishing our salads when the server let the manager know we had been waiting too long. He never approached our table, but he walked past us several times. We continued to wait another 15  minutes then decided to leave.

sK6Flx3PQIu4XsRPzX9Rfw.text: Love the atmosphere.   Pretty, nicely appointed decor and tables with lots of room between them.  Everyone was very pleasant.   Service pretty good, though took a long time to get bread, and hard to find someone to refill your "unlimited" pasta.  The main reason for the 3 stars was mostly mediocre food.  Pasta was good.   Chicken was strange.  Large very thick breast with bland sauce.   Steak was not good enough for the price.  Seems the food is cranked out.  That said, we had an overall pleasant experience.

yAlZuHCRoKNwJUVIXv0XUQ.text: I returned to Lidia's after about three years away, mainly due to the many awesome and fresh restaurants that have popped up in Pittsburgh lately. Spots like Spoon, Grit & Grace, Salt. . .these guys are doing great things, so it was easy to forget about the old standards.  Back to Lidia's. . .the menu has remained consistent, with a nice selection of northern Italian and continental dishes. The special $25 wine list is now the $32 wine list, but there are still a few bargains in there. The food on what looked like a fairly slow Saturday night was good. Not mind-blowing, but the quality was consistent with Lidia's tradition. The braised rabbit dish was delicious, as was the osso buco. I had the "roasted beet salad", which actually had pickled beets, not roasted. But it was tasty.  Now, the problem. . .service was insanely slow and inattentive. Our server was friendly and knowledgeable, but she would disappear for huge chunks of time, leaving us with empty glasses and plates, and no food. All told, from seating to departure, dinner for two lasted exactly three hours, at least an hour was spent just sitting, waiting, wishing. It became aggravating when spending in excess of $100 per person, and at the end of the night you have to track down the waitress to give her your credit card. I expect that at Denny's, but not Lidia's. It really looks like they need a stronger manager keeping things running smoothly, because while the food is still excellent, I saw nobody in control of the dining room. This review could have easily been two stars, but I added one for the tasty rabbit.

74HX6pUux8Irymv_2ng7og.text: We were really looking forward to a high end place to mark a special occasion.The decor is lovely and we were a party of 10 and were seated by the big fireplace and all looked promising. They were out of the wine I had ordered, but had a alternate which was fine. After not really being impressed by the menu I decided on the artichokes as an appetizer and lasagna as a main. A few minutes after the order is placed she comes out and says no lasagna- hmmmm ok- I took the carbonara. Appetizers came out slowly- Caesar salad I tasted was excellent and so were my artichokes. Seems like the starters are always better! 45 minutes later our food came out. Not great- Zappa do peshci cool and rubbery- toasted bread with it toasted til black! I mean burned. Everyone's pasta cold and lacked flavor. Carbonara was gummy. Eggplant parm bland but overly salted. Overall meh..... totally underwhelmed and disappointed. Save your $

hDMwTEnOEeQjpTdOHLxclw.text: Dined here over the weekend- one of the best Italian restaurants I've been to. I loved the lamb shank. It was so good! Although very pricy, I recommend this restaurant to anyone who enjoys foods of different cultures.

ojYvQ2mksbGHVSovjhaOzA.text: My sister and I took our mother to Lidia's for Sunday brunch to celebrate her birthday...this is our favorite weekend spot and is a great place to celebrate something special!   The brunch includes and antipasto bar, entree, and dessert table. For the entree, select the pasta trio and you will never be disappointed! This entree consists of 3 pastas which change daily. They are brought table-side and are refilled/bottomless. The pasta will always consist of some type of stuffed pasta (ravioli), fresh pasta, and imported. You don't have to wait till brunch as this entree is always on the menu; however, the antipasto/dessert bar make attending on the weekend totally worth it- best bang for your buck!!  Be sure to call ahead and make a reservation as this place can get busy! Keep in mind you will have to pay to park and there is no valet during brunch hours.

tLZfXnOBnSv0A7agQqzvQw.text: Food was good, as was the service and atmosphere.  No complaints but nothing wowed me. Although owned by celebrity chef Lidia Bastianich, it just a slightly above-average traditional old-school Italian. Fairly pricey for area given the quality of the food ($180 for 3 - entree/salad/1 glass wine/no dessert with tax and tip). Main advantage is convenience, being next door to our hotel - Homewood Suites.

rwHpgIIFHtkSb8VnbjZjfg.text: This was my first time at Lidia's. The restaurant was half full and it appeared to be fully staffed. However, our service was lacking. We waited awhile to order drink, get drinks, to order, for our food, etc. We didn't have a steady waiter or waitress either but other tables seemed to have one. I was the only one that really liked my meal. I ordered pasta in a garlic oil sauce with squash and it had a good taste for such a simple dish. The other three people with me said the flavoring or their dish was either lacking or too powerful (too much pepper). One got a Caesar salad and said it was good.    A positive was that they do offer a trio endless pasta opinion. I believe the dishes change either daily or weekly and they bring the hot pasta in pans right to your table so you can try all three while also getting as much as you want.

4IORbeojvvtzZ3gXox7xZQ.text: I stayed in the Strip recently and walked two blocks over to Lidia's Italy.  I had seen this restaurant featured a few years back on Lidia's PBS series.  I ordered the baked ziti and my spouse ordered lasagna.  While the ZITI CON POLPETTINE was a generous portion, the lasagna was not.  Honestly my spouse said that he had eaten better lasagna elsewhere, and sampling his, I will agree.  For dessert we ordered the follow:  CROSTATA DI MELE Roasted Apple Crostata with Toasted Almond, Oatmeal Crumble and Vanilla Ice Cream and the SORBETTO E GELATI Trio of House-Made Ice Creams and Sorbets.  The former was not as billed.  I never found the oatmeal crumble and the apples could have been baked more.  The Gelati was so disappointing because each of the three house made ice creams would have starved a Barbie doll. Each was the size of a dippin dot.  Definitely over priced and under portioned.  I suggest if you have a sweet tooth, skip dessert at Lidia's and head on over to Grandpa Joe's Candy Shop on Penn Avenue a seven block stroll on a street one block south of her Smallman Street restaurant.  This place is sweet treat heaven.

7IIN266mvjiWq9y00iYNSA.text: 3 Hours time for 4 of us from being seated to paying the bill. Pasta Trio only had 1 option that we really liked and waited for the pasta too often.  Servers had too many tables each, which affected our service. Both Dinner bills were incorrect at the end of the night. Need I say more ?

z6Y69Vetmr-gGhkkVhH0gw.text: I've always heard kind of mixed things about Lidia's, I was finally able to visit it this past weekend. The parking is a little strange in the area, there were some street spots close by and a large empty lot across the street that I couldn't quite figure out where to enter (or if it was public). I think valet was available. I was able to make the reservation through Open Table. The restaurant space is very nice, it has high ceilings and the far wall looks pretty cool with lighting and wine bottles. The service was not great despite the restaurant not being too full, we had two different people coming to our table but even so we felt like we were a bit neglected at times. Drinks are pricy, the pear martini was blah. They gave us a basket with average bread and crackers and didn't say what the spreads were. Our food took awhile to arrive. I had the ziti and overall it was very uneven in consistency throughout, some parts undercooked and some overcooked (mainly the pasta). They did bring a dessert for someone celebrating a birthday which was nice. Overall though, I think Pittsburgh does better Italian food elsewhere.

All the ladies were handing each other toilet paper since they were out. eFcJHsSR3-x_ZoPJJkiIUA.text: I'm so bummed to have had the experience that my Mom and I did at Lidia's - My parents have gone to this restaurant for years, yet this was only my second time visiting.   We both ordered the lasagna, made with spinach lasagna noodles, a cream bechamel sauce along with a beef bolognese type sauce. This sounded too good not to order and we went for it.   Upon receiving our entrees, I immediately could taste... nothing. It truly tasted like a plate full of ricotta and the noodles were so over cooked and thin, they all slid off of the layers of cheese, etc. then onto the plate, making it look not so appetizing.   I sadly sent it back as I couldn't eat such a tasteless meal, I then order a baked ziti type dish... with meatballs that had chunks of garlic so large I was in desperate need of mouthwash after just the two I tried.   This restaurant really needs some love, either from a new chef or possibly Lidia herself?

sbAL0cICPeff6F7AKbfmKA.text: I was excited to go here, being that it's the only celebrity chef owned restaurant in Pittsburgh. I enjoyed my meal, but I wouldn't say it was anything to get excited about.  The atmosphere was very open, and had nice decor, though felt a little like a large food hall in a university. The bar area was really nice though, and upstairs it looked like there was a nice private event space.  The bread you first get came with a less than appetizing plate of a green and purple/brown spread. We weren't told what it was (would have been appreciated), but it tasted vegetable-y. It was alright, though the look of it dissuaded my partner from trying it.  As an appetizer, we ordered the fritto misto -- a calamari, shrimp, and veggie plate. It was good, but very heavy for an appetizer. I'd definitely recommend having more than two people to share it. Some of the veggies were a bit odd breaded, but the actual calamari and shrimp were good. My only real problem was that it needed salt and pepper badly! I understand not having it on the tables, but make sure things are seasoned in the kitchen!  As far as our actual meal, we were surprised to learn they were already out of two of the four pasta entrees. We went there around six, so this was unexpected and disappointing. However, we both ended up ordering the three course meal, which included a caesar salad, an unlimited sampling of three pre-selected pastas, and a dessert. The three pastas this day were a homemade brown butter / pine nut gnocchi, a homemade fettuccini alfredo, and an imported rigatoni with a delicious onion/pepper/meat sauce. The last was my partner's favorite, and the first mine. It was very good pasta, and though you had unlimited samplings, we couldn't handle any seconds due to the appetizer and salad. I like the concept of a changing pasta sampler, but it's not a wow kind of meal as far as presentation or taste.  We were too full for dessert, but I took a piece of tiramisu home with me and it was awesome. I've yet to hear how the cannolo were (3 small cannoli).  Oh! And the drink I had was awesome -- violet gimlet. I had two.  Overall, I enjoyed my meal, but don't plan on driving an hour to get there again anytime soon. I have to admit I expected a bit more being that it belongs to Lidia Bastionich, particularly in terms of presentations of the restaurant / food, but it was a good meal. The prices were set pretty well for what the food was -- just some good Italian.

nYkAUgIQXjUbZCYpfQk1hg.text: I was very excited to eat here, but the food was mediocre and the service was bad. Not a lot of diners on Saturday. I got the sampler, which includes a buffet/appetizers. I sat down with appetizers when people came with the pasta. Would have been nice to get warm pasta when I was ready to eat it.   The pasta selection was bland. _95X5vrmT82AMU4dszUw5g.text: Hadn't been in probably 10 years with the explosion of dining scene in Pittsburgh. Happy to say in my opinion it still holds up. 8JCgpxFefxU0JGhJuRbwmA.text: The atmosphere of this restaurant is cool, but very average food at best and expensive. Not impressed with the food, considering the owner is so well known. I don't recommend.

yH2LDK87lZ3ZPLul8yYEhA.text: It was a crazy cold night - but i ran out to grab some dinner. I was at the Hampton and ran all the way to Gauchos.   Gauchos has no bar!  I could not stay and ran to Lucky's Bar. They had a bar, but no food and did not accept credit cards - so I continued to run back and ran into Lidia's. rxsnTM7lbU063qMa1RZ6Wg.text: I understand why Lidia's is closing.Food was decent, not great. Service was average and decor is tired. I think it was an either/or scenario....either they remodel/upgrade or they shit down. They made the right choice. Eager to see what takes their place.

fzEyN5rUkWwUn6O0kPMhjg.text: We went on Sunday for the Brunch after visiting The Strip District. This was are first time for visiting Lidia`s. SBsZRVzdso6T8VWKUnfppA.text: The restaurant needs an update for standard meal service. The interior is beautiful and sets a lovely atmosphere. However, the menu is relatively unchanged from 10 years ago. The food is basic with little to really recommend it. Go for the experience not the food.   When Lidia is in town for an event, the place sparkles. The food is much better and adventurous without being too fussy. It is always a set menu so the kitchen can focus on the same courses for each table. The wait staff is always great during the events because the owner and general manager are there for the service and can oversee the staff. Best part is to meet her, get a cookbook autographed and a picture with her. She is so sweet to everyone.  Wonderful lady!

_gxI0c35KF2bxPuKF76MDg.text: Here for dinner on a Sunday night. Wait staff/busboy and manager were 5star. Food not so much. A bit disappointed since we watch Lidia's cooking shows on TV. 2SX4KDNKYt0-40ogHOicqA.text: What a wonderful pre-valentine's dinner experience !  Service was very professional and quick. We both had the pasta trio . Very Good. It included pappardelle pasta with lamb ragu, Bow tie pasta with onions and peppers in a spicy marinara, and spinach and ricotta ravioli in a butter sauce. We also had a great caesar salad and the best Tiramisu I have ever had. The ambiance was cozy and romantic. This is one of our favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh.

V3Bqwe0i_SzsNzZFdJPrWQ.text: Having basic cable for a few years now, I guess I missed who Lidia is. But her restaurant is sure nice. Wonderful and attentive service, nice atmosphere, and large portions of tasty food. I had the gnocchi, which comes with duck ragu - fantastic! I'm a huge fan of duck, and this was a new approach for me. The duck played really well with the thick ragu sauce. Not the best potato dumplings in a gnocchi, but still quite good. My friends dishes were also great, especially the lasagna which was massive.  A nice comfort Italian joint with some unique twists and lovely service. Strikes me as a good spot that can please many different tastes.

U9mxcGMmWO6rBbd-r7TK_g.text: Visited here on Thursday evening (3/20) around 6:30 pm for dinner.  It was not packed although there were several patrons and more walking in as we were leaving.  No wait time.  I noticed upstairs they had a conference room enclosed with glass walls - looks like it would be a nice place for a birthday party or small private engagement.  The food:  Bread - The complimentary bread basket had a mixture of parmesan bread sticks and a couple other bread variations.  It came with two bean type dips and olive oil.  The parmesan bread stick is so good!!! I would've hoarded it all if I weren't on a business trip.  Alas, I had to pretend to be civilized and eat only two.  The bread was good, nothing that stood out, but I love bread I'll eat it anyway.  Fish of the day - I ordered the fish of the day which was rainbow trout over farro.  It came with some sort of creamy sauce that brought everything together perfectly.  A lot of times, the grains that come with the dish are pretty simple, I felt the farro was seasoned to bring out the flavor and texture of it rather than masking it.  I ate every single bit, it was so good.  Dessert - Ordered the biscotti/cookie dessert which came with one scoop of vanilla ice cream with espresso poured over the top in affogato style.  It came with an assortment of cookies, none of which were too sweet.  It came with two of each of Anise and almond biscotti, peanut butter cookie with chopped peanuts, some sort of dark cocoa crispy biscotti type cookie, spice cookie - like ginger molasses, pistachio cookies, and chocolate crinkle cookies. All were pretty small and probably around 1.5" in diameter.  It would be a good dessert to share, but I don't share and I don't share desserts of all things.  The one cookie I liked the least was the crispy dark cocoa thing, I don't know what it is.  I really liked the spice cookie.  The chocolate crinkle cookie was very fudgy and almost like a brownie in a cookie form.   Service was great, although a little pretentious.  Restaurant nice, clean, and upscale, and food came out fast, piping out, and perfect!  Price is fair for the quality.  I would definitely return here!

3AauaC_sUnQ5101MBSr9Xw.text: Horrible. Baby Girl bought a groupon, and we revisited after a about a 4 yr hiatus. I don't remember it being this bad.   Wettest, limpest Caesar salad I ever had, couldn't finish half of it. Pasta trio was bizarre. Three disjointed pastas that fight each other in flavor are piled on your plate. Penne undercooked. Fettuccine flaccid. Only passable pasta was the pear & ricotta ravioli. Too rich, though.   We were there for an hour and fifteen minutes, two courses, and it wasn't that busy. Waitress walked away two times while opening our bottle of wine. Crazy. We got the tiramisu to go, I couldn't deal with this place any more.   Lighting is distracting, felt like I was in a food court in the mall. Carpet was all jacked up. Looked like fraternity house carpet. Clientele was strange...lots of sleeveless T's and baseball hats. I didn't even see that the one time I was at the Olive Garden.  Staff was inattentive and bothered.   I was really looking forward to going, as we love (tangentially) related restaurants Babbo & Esca.   Never again.

Siw-fjSZSUokg9J9440quA.text: ***Over priced and under seasoned*** I still can't believe that we actually had a bad meal in Pittsburgh, especially at this establishment.  This restaurant has been on our list for quite some time, and with restaurant week we finally decided to try something in a different part of town. What a disappointment. The service was average, but the dishes themselves were so incredibly bland that it was like we ate nothing. I ordered the chicken with mushrooms, grana padano, tomatoes, spinach, and garlic-the only thing I actually tasted in that dish was the spinach, and there was way too much of it. My husband ordered the roasted cod al Matalotta with grilled polenta-the only thing he could taste was polenta. Bottom line--although the ambiance and the location was nice, I do not recommend this place.

fuo4rcE2swCrVXXazKDCLQ.text: My family and I went to dinner there last night for my sister and i's birthday. Our waitor Chendo was very friendly, although we had to keep reminding him of things we had ordered. All of the drinks that we ordered were fantastic. The appetizers were very tasty as well. We were in love with the truffles!! For our entrees My boyfriend and my father had both ordered the pasta trio which was good but the rigatoni was very undercooked. My father had ordered a side of meatballs with his trio that never came. My sister had ordered the gnocci and it was lukewarm when it got to the table. My mother had ordered the braised lamb shank with Swiss chard and sweet potatoes, either the Swiss chard was minced or it wasn't on the plate, and she thought that the sweet potatoes were too sweet although my father and boyfriend thought they were okay. Chendo brought her a new side of regular mashed potatoes very quickly. My brother had ordered the beef short ribs and thought his dish was excellent. I had ordered the Sunday special which is braised pork shoulder, Italian sausage, and meatballs over rigatoni. I had no issues with my entree and enjoyed it thoroughly. During dinner my father had ordered a taste of an artichoke liquor for us to try and it didn't come till after we finished our entrees and realized it never came. Over all the experience was great, and my sister and I had a great birthday dinner.

PToUaxF_R0S9IeMmF_1b6g.text: If you've got a taste for real Italian food, then I highly recommend you try this place. Their food is simply out of this world and if you get there for their 3 different pastas for around $20 I guarantee you that you will be blown away with the quality of their food and the great price for 3 different types of pasta. Their staff is the best, they are so pleasant and accommodating and make me feel like they not only want to make sure you have the absolute best Italian food Pittsburgh has to offer, but that you have a very enjoyable experience while eating here. Do yourself a favor and make it a goal to eat here if you haven't already, you will have a great Italian meal and make it regular I'm sure.

q9x21qe3SnhBQD4s2xSmRQ.text: I just really love Lidia's.  I do.  Like really do.  When you walk in, I love the hanging glass blown chandeliers, the look of the open kitchen, the wine prominently displayed on the back wall.  It just looks welcoming and inviting, a little trendy, but not too trendy to make me feel like I'm not cool enough to eat there!  The hostess is always friendly and quick to seat you.  I'd definitely recommend reservations if possible as they can get pretty busy both on weekdays and especially weekends.  The food is amazing.  Have you seen her cooking shows on PBS?  It's just like that, times 1000 because you actually get to eat it, not just watch her cook it.  I've never had something I didn't like here, though I do have some favorites.  The duck breast is wonderful.  Perfectly cooked and prepared with a sweet cherry sauce all served over polenta.  Wait, I think I'm drooling :-)  Their tasting trio of pastas changes daily with one imported and two dry pastas and varying sauces based on the day.  Most of the time these are delicious, I've had a very few where they are good, but don't knock my socks off.  Just depends on your taste.  The servers do an excellent job describing the daily specials, so go with their recommendations and input.  Oh yeah, don't forge the tasting trio is all you can eat so come hungry!  I almost forgot the breadbasket!  Always delicious with focaccia bread, cheesy breadsticks, and Tuscan style Italian bread served with a kalamata olive spread, garbanzo bean spread (amazing!) sitting in a moat of olive oil.  It's hard not to fill up on the bread!  If you enjoy wine, try their wine of the month by glass or bottle.  I often get it and have never had one I didn't enjoy.  The servers are always on point with excellent wine and food recommendations based on your personal tastes.  They are quick with refills, more bread and are very capable of dealing with reasonable special requests.  It's really a blessing that Lidia picked Pittsburgh as a location for one of her restaurants.  If you haven't checked it out, no better time than now for some delicious Italian food and wine!

cDIz_t6HqIwu8z5NhKUnLg.text: Lidias is a classy restaurant in the strip district. There's valet parking for $6 if you so wish to do so.  You step inside and see that its not a super large restaurant,  but it is large enough and has a cozy feel to it.  The light fixtures are brightly colored glass and are beautiful.  Take a look at the bar on the back wall, because it is very striking.  You dont have to dress up, but it doesnt hurt to look a little bit because you dont want a chandelier to upstage you!  The menu is a two pager and everything looked very good.  My group all ordered the pasta trio.  The trio included a spaghetti type with roasted cauliflower and tomatoes, penne with ragu and mushroom ravioli. Each pasta was delicious and it was impossible to choose a favorite.  The servings are unlimited so you dont have to miss any pasta for very long before more is brought to you.  Each pasta satisfied a different food craving (light, hearty and rich) and this is what made it difficult to choose a favorite.  Dessert was also very good and I had split the chocolate cake with my uncle. Just in case you're wondering,  the chocolate cake has no shredded coconut so eat away! The description mentions coconut several times and ordinarily I'm scared that it will have shredded coconut,  but this was safe.    Lidias was a great experience and I'm glad I went.  I think its worthy of 5 stars because the service, food and atmosphere was wonderful.  Tutti a tavola a mangiare!

Olq24DLjxccQI2gekg_YZQ.text: This restaurant has been on my bucket list for years, and finally last night I got the chance to go!  We walked in at 7pm on Saturday evening and were seated right away.  Parking on the street after 6pm is free btw, a friendly lot attendant told us that so we wouldn't pay in a lot.  We ordered three appetizers- meatballs, grilled octopus, and focaccia with preserved tomatoes, mozzarella and a pork tapenade type spread.  The meatballs were fantastic, they were served over large pieces of grilled bread and we should have eaten them first because by the time we got to them the bread was a little soggy.  Rookie mistake on our part.  The focaccia was almost like a pizza, and it had a very smoky flavor to it that was just ok... it wasn't something I'd order again but I'm glad we tried it.  But the clear all star from our appetizers was the octopus.  It was grilled and dressed simply and served with asparagus and spring vegetables.  It was exactly what I love best about Lidia's recipes- good fresh seasonal food simply prepared.  The octopus wasn't chewy at all.  Amazing.  For dinner I ordered the Zuppa di Pesce, and it was quite good (though it needed salt).  There was a lot of seafood in there and the mussels in particular were really great.  They were seared first which is a nice touch.  It was served over couscous, and I think in retrospect pasta would be a better choice because there wasn't very much couscous and it ended up sort of blending in.  My friend got the pasta tasting- three cheese ravioli with pear, a corn Alfredo over pasta and a hollow spaghetti pasta with a red sauce.  She said the pear ravioli was an unexpected combo but the other two were fantastic- and two of the pastas were made in house.  For dessert it was my friend's birthday so our server brought out a trio of sorbets- a blueberry, a pineapple and cherry flavor that actually tasted like pineapple and coconut and had candies orange rinds in the bottom that were amazing, and a raspberry (or maybe mixed berry) sorbet that was also lovely.  We would have never ordered sorbet but it ended up being the perfect ending to our meal and that pineapple one with the candied orange was AMAZING.  I'm surprised this restaurant wasn't more crowded.  We had a great meal and will absolutely return.

_3XAmKZnQsUKn_2N3tP5Ww.text: Writing this review saddens me: we were so pumped to try Lidias! We heard by word of mouth how great this place is and in our personal Italian Food Tour this was going to be the gold standard.  Our experience with the staff and service was amazing. Everyone was so excited to be working there and that definitely boosted our moods! They have a staff member for everything; the waiter, the cheese grater, the food deliverer, and the food clearer! The ambiance of the place was less formal than I was expecting; more tren We loooooved their complimentary assorted bread bowl and their home made pesto paste in oil and garbanzo bean paste in oil!  I ordered the Gnocchi with duck bolognese and my boyfriend ordered their specialty: pasta trio which was a creamy gnocchi, spicy shrimp pasta and pesto tortellini (unlimited!!). We get so excited when we hear Italian restaurants make their own pasta! My gnocchi was very well cooked. However my boyfriends pasta and tortellini were mushy. (This may have something to do with the "unlimited" aspect; maybe it's being constantly warmed and that made it mushy?). We also don't think any of the dishes were spectacular regarding flavor; just very bland. My duck was amazing and tender, I just wish the bolognese was more flavorful to bring the dish together.  I would definitely come back because maybe it was an off night! I'd love to try their daily special or a protein dish!

iDIqphL2Zxh2__SiROzLgA.text: We had a horrible experience today at Lidia's. I'm just disappointed in the staff and management more than anything else. We had just sat down for brunch and the waitress had literally just poured water for my father-in-law and she knocked it over and the entire glass landed on him and soaked him.  We all stood up to discuss what to do and the waitress just said sorry and walked away. We decided to leave since he was soaked and I told the hostess what happened, hoping maybe she would get a manager and she just said okay. I was so upset that I asked to see the manager on duty. His response was about the same as everyone else. Literally just an "okay."  What was I expecting? A more immediate response from the staff and management. An "I'm so sorry this happened, what can I do to rectify this? We want to turn this situation around for you because we value that you decided to dine with us." It was just clear they could care less. They basically ruined our Father's Day brunch. I'm now sitting at Eat n' Park waiting for a to go order.   I've worked in the service industry for years. I understand that accidents happen. I've dumped orange juice on a dudes crotch on Christmas Eve! I was basically bowing down and saying I'm so sorry what can I do... and I was a teenager! The real issue is the staff response and, most astoundingly, the managements response. I'm just really disappointed and we have been customers for years, as this is my husband's favorite restaurant.   I truly am not seeking compensation or anything free. I most importantly want this poor service to be addressed. I just would have expected more from Lidia's, more than a mumbled sorry and "okay."

RK6ksPxLIL_VTmWF3CZZiQ.text: It took me a while to write and publish this review because I was so distraught after my experience at this establishment. I almost thought that if I could suppress the memory, then I could forget that certain types of discrimination still exist in our society.  My experience is from when I dined at this restaurant on May 5th. To preface, it was marathon weekend (I was running!), my parents were in from out of town and it was my mom's birthday. After seeing raving reviews online we decide to visit Lydia's in the Strip.   Have you ever been ONE hour deep into waiting for your food and wished you had not ever came to a certain restaurant? No, you haven't. Probably because a sane person would know 1 hour into never seeing sight of their appetizer that they should leave.  We ordered fried calamari for appetizer and 3 entrees which consisted of lasagna, Ravioli and pork shank. After one hour, we hadn't even gotten our appetizer yet and started looking around for signs of food. Our waitress eventually saw our concerned faces and said she would check on our appetizer. After some more time of waiting, my dad finally tried to get our waitress' attention to inquire about the food. She exclaimed "I have nfo idea, I told them and they said they are cooking it!" When we finally got our appetizer the server kind of placed it at the end of the table and hurried away. We thought it was so odd that 1.) He did not place it in the middle of the table 2.) He didn't even make eye contact with us.  However we quickly learned why: we were appalled to see that there was 3 pieces of calamari and the rest were just tempura vegetables. Suddenly it started to make sense why it took an hour to get our appetizer? Maybe they never had any calamari?  After some more time of absurd waiting: tables around us were clearing out, other patrons were finishing their dinner and getting dessert menus...we were still sitting around twiddling our thumbs, picking at crumbs off the table.    Our food finally did make it to us but after more than an hour of waiting. We were never issued an apology. And frankly by this point all of our moods had been ruined. The whole experience made me feel a little mistreated. I hate playing the race card. But it's very hard not to when you're the only table that is an ethnic family and the only table getting mistreated. In the end, we asked for our untouched foods to be boxed and for our checks. Our waitress then informed us that the manager was kind enough to not charge us for the appetizer. At which point I insisted that it be added back to the bill. You see, my problem with this establishment isn't that I can't afford to pay for what I ordered, it's how we were treated as patrons, and in this case, patrons who do not look like the majority of the people that dine here. I would have much rather if the manager had came to our table and expressed some sort of apology.

KK36MhiEyaSuCDbHNuAn4g.text: I was really craving Italian and most things in/around downtown seemed tacky or expensive.  This seemed like a nice choice in the middle.  Mixed reviews about the place. Overall, friendly and attentive service and decent Italian food.  Not quite what I was expecting but it served it's purpose for the night.

KlGCOwnHfTKmsI7TX4Nm2w.text: Went to Lidias for my first time after being in Pittsburgh for 4 years and I wish I had gone sooner! The atmosphere of this place is very welcoming and fancy yet cute. 3uea2NWIvCHQd15GYMz7eQ.text: Came here with a large group for a dinner meeting and the service was extremely slow. The event started at 6 pm and we did not get bread until after 6:30. _KmYxiNXYD8AzGHe-2H7EQ.text: So disappointed in the service!!!! Is just because it's Valentines weekend?? I sure hope! Everything took forever-glad we were scheduling ahead with theater tickets. We saw our waitress mixing our drinks--commendable, but it seemed to indicate there was a shortage of staff. Food was good-not great-took forever between ordering drinks, appetizers, entrees.  I had the duck, which tasted good but was awful to cut--dull steak knives, perhaps? I'd try it again, but for the price, I'd say 2.5 stars would be fair.  Long line out the door when we were leaving, bout the table beside us left uncleared for about 30 minutes. Drinks sat at the bar, unserved for over 20 minutes.

qW8U-SW_H1TTWcHTxZMZ2A.text: If you are planning to order lunch don't bother making the trip. They have locked the door. Lidia's... I would suggest you edit your phone answering messages to reflect this. :(

iUOFEcwKoBQ1Q_KDWW-Kjw.text: Myself and a few friends visited Lidia's during Restaurant Week, so naturally it was pretty busy. We waited about an hour after being told 20 minutes, so that was a little annoyance. But, we got drinks at the bar so it passed the time quickly.   The drinks were just okay, they definitely did not go shy on the alcohol, which is always a good thing. I originally ordered the Black Maple and I really did not like it. I enjoy bourbon but this was a little much. But, my friend ordered the Violet Gimlet and we ended up liking each other's drinks more so we switched and it worked out.  When we got to our table, our waitress was friendly and very attentive to us. We all got Caesar salads for our appetizers and they were tasty. I love a good Caesar salad. As for our entrees, everyone but me got the Tasting Trio. They had people walking around the restaurant constantly filling up your plate if you wanted more, which I thought was convenient. As for my dish, I ordered Pollo Al Limone which I enjoyed. It was refreshing, I enjoyed that it included spinach.  The reason I am only giving three stars is because 3 out of the 4 people I went with got sick afterwards. My boyfriend actually threw up in the middle of the night. I do not know if this was because of the food or something else. It may have been a coincidence but I am hesitant to return for this reason!

VfkfEblUwCzyjOD_yjdZUA.text: I wish Yelp gave 1/2 stars because 3 isn't good enough but 4 is to much. So really this place is 3 1/2 stars. Came in for restaurant week. Our server Lori was fantastic. Very knowledgeable professional and nice. The atmosphere is great. The service from the bussers to management was top notch. Sadly the food was not. Got the pasta trio. I know it changes daily but this day wasn't good. The bolognese sauce tasted like it was from a jar. My other option was a tortellini with a butter cream sauce. That sauce was non existent. 3rd option in the trio was a linguini with also a butter cream sauce! That also was non existence. The whole thing was bland. Why have two pastas with the same sauce??When I took my leftovers home I added many things . That is something I shouldn't have to do.  My husband said the salmon was ok but typical. The only positive food  item was the tiramisu!! It was the best I've ever had. So overall everything but the main courses was good. Which is sad. Not sure I will be back.  Oh and one note, always check the price of the wine that the server recommends as she of course recommended the most expensive but I knew what she was doing.

oqsyodsWvFHA2QylVtr1sg.text: A pleasant dinner at Lidia's, I came alone, the bartender helped me to find a seat, the inner deco was luxury. I ordered the pasta testing trio ($23) which was very impressive, I actually love all the pastas I tried here. The Caesar salad was nice too. Haven't got chance to try the tiramisu Because I had too many pastas...hope I can taste it next time.

TQZyMQfpoRbhRro6KeVsow.text: We have experienced Becco and Del Posto (one of our most favourite) in NYC. I would say Lidia's in Pitt is very similar to Becco the pasta's of the day, the fucilli pasta with meat sauce was very good and the cheese ravioli had a delicate savoury flavour. The garlic & oil pasta was way too garlicky and sometimes came with very pungent burnt garlic.  They had some interesting appetizers; tuna cruda with blood orange & avocado in a creamy oil infused with jalapeno pearls, not impressed with my small wedge of Burrata and smoked Salmon, not sure this fits with a traditional Italian menu.  Also I was not impressed with my Barolo braised rib and spaetzle. It tasted like pouched meat with absolutely no flavour and the spaetzle was drowning in oil or better again with no recognizable seasoning. I wanted to send complain but our waitress was so nice, I just left more than half in my dish and took it home. Fortunately the waiter offered me some of the pasta to taste, which filled me up. My daughter will be adding this braised meat to a savoury tomato sauce and do justice for this quality piece of meet.  Also their wines were less than impressive for the price point they are charging.  I regret not paying the $25 corking fee and bringing my own wine.  Less than impressive experience, but had to try Lidia's.

sLS-DQAvBl9-g-lvIwfadA.text: Lidia's is an Italian restaurant near downtown Pittsburgh that's been around for quite awhile. It's a massive restaurant so you're sure to be able to find a table at any time any day.  My wife, daughter, and I stopped by on a Saturday for brunch since most other places nearby had a line. Their brunch is $29 a person and comes with unlimited buffet options from salads to breads to desserts. Then you pick an entree. We chose the pasta trio. Waiters came to our table constantly to drop off the three types of pastas. They also had coffee flowing freely into our mugs.  The experience was positive and the food decent, but nothing to write home about. We wouldn't run back.

dWDHH1hCQEyTzAwjppZcNA.text: When we were in Kansas City on business a few years back,  we liked Lidia's so much that we went twice during that trip.   So when we realized there was a Lidia's in Pittsburgh, we made a reservation for the night we'd be in town.   Umm...  Big disappointment.   Our meal was lackluster.   Our server,  Casey,  was off-putting and inattentive.  And the cost was completely out of whack for the experience.    Lidia's...  At least the Pittsburgh version...  Is the textbook example of all show and no go.

GveyxdA7ZiyqLffUEQng8A.text: This was an ok experience. There was nothing that was bad but nothing that was extremely good either. Our entire table ordered the bottomless pasta trio ($23). The servers were attentive-- they checked on us often and kept our plates filled with pasta. But the food itself was under-seasoned and not all that impressive. There was no salt or Parmesan or red pepper flakes on the table. I want flavor in my face, Lidia! And if you're not going to give it to me, I want to be able to shake it on.

rj6j6Aitv4aJ06VOsxC6DQ.text: We were all steaked out from eating at Ruth Chris's and decided to try Italian.  One of the folks found this place on OpenTable, so we decided to give it a try.  The space itself is beautiful.  The room has a very modern feel, even though I was told that the restaurant was 17 yrs old.  I loved the wall settings made out of cut out wine casks.  Very creative.  On to the food.  For starters, Dr. M and I got the Polipo (Grilled Octopus, Warm Potatoes, Caper, Red Onion, Gaeta Olives) and the Polpette (Heritage Pork and Beef Meatballs Braised in Tomato with Grilled Ciabatta).  These were both excellent dishes.  The word that came to mind as I was eating them was "soft", something the Heiress Apparent use to say as a child to describe something that was very tender.  The grilled octopus was nicely grilled and had a nice charred flavor to it.  My only complaint about the meatballs was I wish I had ordered more.  The sauce was amazing and serving them on the grilled bread was a great idea.  Although the bread was toasted, it got soggy in a good way from the sauce and the juices from the meatball.  For dinner I got the Gnocchi with Braised Duck Ragu and Dr M got the Ziti con Polpettine (Baked Ziti Pasta with Fontina, Tomato Sauce, and Meatballs).  Both these dishes were excellent.  I was surprised at the amount of duck in the ragu, very plentiful and well done.  For dessert I got the Tiramisu...pretty standard, but good.  Some of the folks at our table got the pasta trio.  Like other reviews, I would concur that while there was plenty of pasta being served, it did not have much in the way of flavor.  My friend next to me ordered this dish, so I sampled off of his plate.  There was a ravioli that was pretty good, but can't recall what was in it.  But out of the three (fettuccine, rigatoni and ravioli), the ravioli was the best.  I will say that they did keep the pasta coming out for those that ordered it.  The service was great.  Our server (Marty) was very attentive.  He gave us a history of the restaurant, told me about the back wall made out of wine casks as well as the interesting overhead lights.  We also got into a discussion about a rose cider that his girlfriend drinks...didn't even know that they made a rose cider.   Yelp doesn't do half stars, so I would have done 3.5 based on my meal.  But tasting my neighbor's pasta trio dropped it down to 3.  Our meal was definitely 3.5 stars.  They really need to spice up that pasta trio and use that red sauce that they make.  It is awesome and would make a welcome change to the trio offering.

VdwQ3Ot-L1dx5D-Wxy2Q0g.text: This was our second time visiting from out of state (the last time was three years ago). The front of house staff were great and we really enjoyed our server, Cindy. She was attentive, friendly, but also allowed us to enjoy our meal together. We had our son with us and appreciated that she gave us the same service as the 7 top sat shortly before us and did not act as if we were less important despite obviously having a smaller check.   The unlimited pasta was delicious and included a hollow spaghetti in a tomato and meat sauce, fettuccine with broccoli pesto and shrimp, and pear/cheese ravioli. They were all great especially for the price, but the shrimp was a bit under-seasoned. The only reason why I did not rate as 5 Stars was because overall the food was somewhat inconsistent (excellent pasta, average bread and spread, average cocktail, good dessert) in quality and price.

kP9tSdTVKPxtyalp9vAPTQ.text: Good, for a "celebrity name" restaurant.  Actually, I typed in another adjective, but didn't was to have my review flagged.  The pasta was  very fresh and well prepared, and the service was top-notch.  The non-pasta dishes were more common

M9SwS5mJhIK5eGgKBn8XtQ.text: I go to Lidia's once a year when I am in town for Thanksgiving. I like the ambiance and the decor, although this year our corner table had chairs that sunk WAY down - we wanted to ask for telephone books. I usually choose one of the special salads and have the gnocchi with duck ragu; it is superb! So much flavor and the gnocchi are perfect. This year, though, there was a special fall prix fixe menu with Winter Squash. The ravioli with balsamic drizzle were delicious. I choose quail with apples and squash for my main course and was very satisfied. Terrific glaze! The dessert, however, was over the top! Creme fraiche and pumpkin ice creams, caramel sauce, AND pumpkin fritters. We enjoyed a couple of the $28 bottles. No, they aren't stellar, but for the price they are all good food wines. Everyone in our party enjoyed the meals and we will definitely return.

f0jjodYM2tir4FpTzFmDlQ.text: It's funny that I went here for Sunday brunch and have yet to visit the NYC location, but se la vie.  Lidia's Pittsburgh is good.  Not spectacular, but really very good, and it's a welcome respite from the Olive Garden and the other Italian chains that seem to make up the Pgh area & the rest of the US.  Also, I give it kudos for its location in the Strip District.  Decor-wise, there is a comfortable and easy ambiance mixed with a slight artsiness that I liked.  Plus there were only friendly and helpful servers/hosts etc., which is always worth a lot, in my opinion.  While we were probably underdressed, there was zero attitude about it, and that's just not  not something I would encounter in NYC.   Again, the food was really good.  Not amazing, mind you, but very tasty.  I had the homemade pasta, which was brought tableside piping hot, in addition to the homemade salads and other fare at the buffet table.  A Bloody Mary, (or Champagne, if you prefer) is included in the brunch as well, making for a great deal!!  (I think the whole brunch was like $17 including drinks and dessert.)  The desserts were quite good as well.  This would be a great spot for a large party too.  Unfortunately, I do feel like it's missing that little something extra that makes a restaurant truly great, but it is absolutely worth a try.  You will enjoy your meal here.

-Q3Iee06GZd_WfEpuRQCpA.text: Jeez...Has it really been a month since I've been here as I look at the receipt.  Well, I'll try to fill in the blanks.  This may be one of my new fav' brunch spots.  I'm not a fan of brunches as I detest most buffet style dining (has to do with my germophobia), sneeze guards...etc. Howeve, this is the type of brunch I can deal with.  First let's start with the space.  It's a beautiful restaurant that's been here for a few years.  Lidia of PBS fame has only three restaurants I believe (one in nyc, one in kc, and for some reason one in pgh).  As an aside I was told when I asked that one of the reasons lidia chose pittsburgh is because the ratings for her cooking show are better in this small metro than any other urban setting.  I dont' remembe all the details of the space except there were very high ceilings and ornate chandeliers (sp?).  We sat at the long bar and had a great professional bartender.  The bar offers a birds eye view into the open kitchen with many "back of the house" folks running about in organized confusion.  It's a bit busier today than usual Isuspect because the matriarch herself "lidia" is here barking orders and checking plates.  I'm told she only visits a few times a year and is here for the tomatoe dinner...Btw, Lidia in person looks very much like her profile on tv,,, she seems warm, genuine and very...how should I say..."grandmotherlike".  She comes out of the kitchen signs afew autographs and then has a seat by herself sipping an espresso watching the show go past...Okay, onto the food one of the main reason's I like this brunch is because the brunch entree's are cooked to order and offer some interesting options outside of your typical brunch fair.  It's relatively reasonable at $22 for everything including a "well" bloody mary.  The brunch starts with a delicious assortment of warm bread from the in house bakery served with three flavored butters.  I believe they are one with "crunchy" sugar, apricot and strawberry.  I like the crunchy one the best and quite frankly could have made a meal out of the bread and butter alone.  The buffet portion (if you will) has some fun options such as a great antipasta platter, all cheese and meats served at the perfect temperature with some house made pickles.  Also, there is a nice frittata (think italian omelette) along with a couple assorted salads and fruit.  You then have your choice of about a dozen main courses...everything from there famous pasta tasting trio for those who really want to "carb up" to beef tenderloin and chicken.  Annie orders this DELICIOUS duck pasta.  I don't think it's on the traditional brunch menu but it is soft pillows of al dente' pasta stuffed with a savory mix of duck and spices served in a small bowl with a dusting of cheese.  It was quite good.  I order the chicken livers, which are flavorful quick seared chicken livers, about medium rare served with polenta and fried onions.  I'm not a big polenta fan and the dish could have used some sauce, but overall it was a nice flavorful brunch.  You also get to peruse the dessert menu for the $22, but we skipped it.  We found the food quite good and the service outstanding.  Now, granted the boss was there so it was everyones "A game"...I don't care even without the best efforts I'm guessing this will become a somewhat regular stop for us.

Bnhae42QFMrwa6UvvVesWg.text: I've been to Lidia's a few times before and figured I'd leave a review after today's trip.  We arrived a bit early for our reservation and they were able to seat us right away.  Even with a fairly packed dining room, the place wasn't too loud.  If you have any old people in your group, they can seat you downstairs as I don't think they have an elevator (I prefer being upstairs overlooking looking the dining room, it's a nice touch).  The Lobster Arancini were cooked perfectly with no crunchy, undercooked risotto inside.  The only downside was that there were just 3 (we had 4 people) and they were tiny so it was almost impossible to split them.  As for entrees, the gnocchi topped with a duck ragu are a fantastic dish, not too rich and the gnocchi simply melt in your mouth.  The Zuppa di Pesce has a wonderfully balanced broth which wasn't oversalted (a surprise given the amount of shellfish) and tasted like it might have had Sherry wine in it.  I think I counted 7 or 8 different items in this seafood hodgepodge.  As for service, it was quite good and we were done with 3 courses in a bit over an hour.  Lidia's certainly ranks up there as one of my favorite Italian restaurants in the city.

1u0pfwOS3liaX8FkNaSUPA.text: We had a great experience at Lidia's.  I would give this a 4.5 if I could.  We started with the Prosciutto San Danielle and Asparagus and Boiled egg salad. The salad was the perfect foil to the salty prosciutto. Very nice.  We loved the bread basket with the the scoop of ground chickpeas in pesto.  We each had a salad.  My partner ordered the pasta tasting (more on this in a moment) which came with a Caesar Salad and my friend Carlos and I split the Roasted Beet salad.  For entree, I had the gnocchi with Duck ragu.  Wow.  Really fantastic.  Nice handmade gnocchi with a rich duck sauce that almost seemed like a confit.   Carlos had the grilled calamari with corona beans and escarole.  It was light and delicious in a heady broth that was spiked with Thyme.   My partner, Steven had the pasta tasting.  Kinda like Italian Rodizio, three housemade pastas of the day are served and by roving waiters with copper skillets.  They keep on serving you pasta for as long as you want to eat.  That night the pastas were a spinach and ricotta ravioli in a butter thyme sauce, pappardelle in a pulled pork sauce and Penne with eggplant.  Steven liked two out of the three.  He found the pulled pork sauce to be overwhelming.  The raviolis were a treat and when the servers brought Steven his first round, he energetically asked "would you like to try one?"  Of course I would!  that was indicative of all the service we encountered.  Very casual, friendly and efficient.  What more could you ask for?  Desserts were superlative.  I had the Cranberry Torta with homemade pistachio ice cream and Steven had the Panna Cotta with Marinated dry fruits.  Both were exemplary.  The decor is lovely.  All in all a great experience.  I do understand when others say that perhaps they expected a bit more, and perhaps I agree with them, considering that this is Lidia Bastianich's place, but if you dissassociate the name with the experience I think you will find that it's a great meal at a reasonable price and what's wrong with that?

QGdZWsrDKqre16yLPGSjJw.text: We went to treat A's parents for their anniversary - his mom has been obsessed with this lady forever. I had an amazing lobster risotto, A had the osso bucco, and his mom tried the pasta trio, which was divine. His dad had something spicy and in marinara sauce...looked godd. Neat atmosphere, and knowledgeable waitstaff...

iK3_laA-jiJ9K0VuPnQluQ.text: Fine Italian dining at a reasonable price and by reasonable, I mean, it's less expensive than a Michelin  starred French restaurant. The atmosphere is pretty fancy...high ceilings, white table clothes, snooty looking hosts and waiters, however, looks are deceiving. This is a family-style restaurant, disguised as a fine dining.   We went here with 6 adults and 2 young children...arriving a little too early for dinner, they let us wait inside. I was hoping they'd give us some free appetizers, but no such luck =(. They seated us right at 5p and seats started filling up fast, so it was probably a good idea we got there early. We ordered 5 of the pasta trios and I ordered the Zuppe di Pesce (seafood stew). The pasta was good...I wouldn't say it was amazing, but definitely worth the price...$20 for just the pasta, but yo u can add a ceasar salad and desert for I think $7. For people that don't know, everyday, there are 3 different pasta dishes the chef makes for this pasta trio. They have servers for each of the individual pastas (pretty neat IMO). They give you a sampling of the 3 at first, which, quite honestly was plenty. Then you can pick one, two or even all three for the subsequent rounds. I don't know if it's all you can eat, but even the big eaters were done after their 3rd plate. There is a child's menu, but our kids eat like birds, so we asked if they could have a little of the pasta. The servers were very accomodating...bringing everyone plates to share. My wife ordered the pasta trio with a salad and desert. The ceasar was perfect (she shared it with me) and she had tiramisu that was probably the best we've ever had. The Zuppe di pesce (my entree) was AMAZING...I'm a seafood lover though. Overall, I'd say this is an upgraded version of Olive Garden...which is NOT a bad thing.

swxn5uLtJuLijKi_6OW2oA.text: A lot of hype on how "amazing" it was.  Totally overrated.  So terribly overpriced for such mediocre food.  Growing up 100% Italian, I know what Italian food is.  The great reviews are obviously from people who have no idea what Italian food is. Total disappointment.  Never again.  I make far better in my own kitchen.  But, if you're a fan of a famous name that serves underwhelming food for top notch price, have at it.

sd_43sHqDP8p-XSZ5LulXQ.text: Lidia's is a Pittsburgh gem!  Not uptight in the least, but supremely accommodating and professional.  I would recommend the weekend brunch special (antipasto buffet, entree, dessert buffet, and a cocktail).  Very considerate of dietary restrictions: vegetarians and vegans.  Downright delicious with no frills!

LAb4Ew5FbojfD0WmA8um_g.text: Overall this was good Italian food if you're ready to venture into something more asventerous than Olive Garden.  I had the pasta trio and thought the ravioli was amazing.  Everything else was pretty good, but a butternut squash ravioli made the meal.  Be prepared to spend about $30 a person for the full experience and I'll remember this meal for a while.

tRNi2pBw8ZS_2J9t1fu5-w.text: I was really excited to go to Lidia's while in Pittsburgh for work.  Had some drinks at the bar and they have an extensive Italian wine list.     Our service was a little delayed but once our waiter was available he was knowledgeable and continued to check on us. He was a little awkward but attentive.    The mussels were a little "fishy" to my taste but the remaining dishes we ordered were great and so were the bread bowl options.  I enjoyed a gnocchi special.  The pasta trio is typically the recommended choice but I wasn't in the mood for what was prepared that day.  Overall I would give it a B.

W-1mQj4edth7H8hb09O6Aw.text: I had their three pasta dinner in which they bring out to you endless amounts of their homemade or imported pasta dishes. Each one was absolutely delicious, and the service was wonderful.

Ld6Q7yYMF9NanutTB45Egw.text: Went here for a quick lunch on a Friday at 12:35. We were seated right away. Had chicken panini and pasta trio. Super! Highly recommend the pear and cheese ravioli. Service was fantastic!

9ULpCGCoD4FprxGOk1xaAA.text: My husband and I had the pleasure of dining at Lidia's on Thanksgiving day.  The food was good.  No Butterball turkey here!
